The game offers a very unique and interesting gameplay experience. It is well crafted and stable and no bugs have come to my knowing. It has some minor balance issues and design flaws. Overall i can recommend this game to people interested in RTS, who like to take on a challenge. This game is difficult. Stay away from it if you can not stand losing over and over again.

The UI is thought out well and is very intuitive.
Visuals are done nicely, no eyesore to be expected.
The current standard price of about 20$ is more than justified.



What is it about?
To sum it up: The russian devs have built a hero management simulation on top of a classic RTS basis. It plays pretty fresh, and feels damn good.

Basically, the units you build have minds on their own. There is no way to directly control them.
They do hero stuff, they wander around in search of monsters and loot, they level up just like all heroes do and can become even better with shinier armor and bigger swords.
Given some time, success and little dying they can develop from a wooden sword swinging wannabe knight to a professional murdering machine.

They misjudge their chances and die in silly ways quite often, hindering the individual progress, cost you a lot of money and ultimately, cause you to fail the map. So, the chaotic bunch needs to be directed somehow.
This is where the player jumps in. You can interact with various Spells on a smaller scale, but: What do heroes like ? Exactly, shiny things and money.

Orders are handled by issuing quests. For example, there is a wolves den which annoys you. You can create a quest for your guys, by putting a reward on it. Heroes will take on that quest if they feel like its worth it, and soon, the wolves den will be history.
The earned money then goes to that heroes purse and he will use it to buy Potions, enchant or buff himself in Guildhouses or buy new equipment if he doesn't die before he can spend it.
The money spent by heroes comes back to your purse for the most part, so its a game of give and take. With the added risk of the hero dying, resulting in loss of that money with additional resurrection costs. (These can become very very costly with increasing levels)

All Heroes will be acting selfishly on their own by default, giving little to no support to the competing" heroes. Later on

Hey all.

I'm coming from Majesty 1.

When I'm playing the original Majesty, I always imagine myself as Vetinari, the patrician of Ankh-Morpork. Obviously the city, which I am building is Ankh-Morpork. Dunno, I always imagined Ankh-Morpork just like that.

I would like to have sequel, which have art and AI of original Majesty. Not a generic gimped RTS.

Nevertheless, if we look at this as a separate game and not a sequel, then it's pretty nice.

Conclusion is: if you want some new experience in strategy games definitely get this. If you're an old-school fan of Majesty, then I don't think that you will like this, because it's lacks the atmosphere of original game. It's better for you to view this as a stand-alone game.

I've never heard of Majesty 2 until the recent steam sale.  I'm a fan of real time and turn based strategy games and I must say that I've thoroughly enjoyed playing this game.  Just finished the original and kingmaker campaigns, it sure was fun.

Don't think multiplayer works for this game but singleplayer is great.  In 64 hours of gameplay it has crashed on me only once.  So can't say it has many bugs.  The game is nicely polished and has good graphics for its age.  Haven't played Majesty 1, the graphics there are a bit of a turn off unfortunately, although many people think the gameplay of the older version is better.

The campagn missions can be very difficult but they are beatable.  The increasing difficulty pushes you to explore the game more and read up on some strategies if you get really stuck.  When you are finally able to beat that difficult mission,  like the Rat King or The Avatar, then it feels really satisfying :)  With the Rat King mission I built a mage guild and then a wizard tower and kept activating it to protect my warriors until they levelled up.

Economy is very important in this game, try to position your marketplace next to a trade post and then build a tower next to the market so the tax collector doesn't have very far to walk.   Group your economic buildings like the blacksmith and the potions bazaar next to that tower as well.

There are a variety of strategies available with each mission.  You can create 'tanking' groups of 3 clerics + 1 dwarf.  Although groups don't seem to retreat as well as individual heroes.  Rangers are a good early to mid game option.  Some players build the Hall of Lords straight away.  Some of the cheap lords like levelled up Rogues and Rangers can be very useful in the early game and mid game, and that's usually the most crucial time.  A levelled up lord is not always the best option, it may be better to have lower level templars with good weapons so they are cheaper to buy.  And so on a so forth.

Sure the first game may have more options but Magesty 2 also offers alot of good gameplay so I think this game is sometimes rated unfairly, because it is a great game.  And if its on sale then its definitely worth it :)

reviewText:
Some changes from Majesty 1, of which a lot of my childhood was spent playing.

Improved AI: You can use this to cheese any map, as your peasants actually repair things in Majesty 2, hero AI is a lot better, with heroes making better choices. With new flags like guarding, you never have to worry about a skeleton ruining your entire economy because it got lucky and killed the caravan carrying much needed gold.

Stronger guards: Palace and guard tower guards can now stand toe to toe with moderately strong enemies. Tax collectors seem much happier in this game. Arrows come with the guard tower, no need to spend gold researching them.

Stronger classes in general: Mages and Rangers no longer die in 1-2 hits from rats anymore, clerics not only do actual damage, but they are even harder to kill than before. Mages do not have the extreme overkill capacity as they did in Majesty 1 if they survived to level 10, but they make up for it with better defenses / ai / and utility (freezing enemies). Elves have been buffed to the point of being useful unless you have to go with dwarves to fight early dragon onslaughts.

Skeletons now reliably killable by level 1 Warriors: Skeletons are no longer magic resist / dodge gods and for the player, dwarves have taken their place for fighting strong magic monsters like dragons.

Parties: You can now assign 4 heroes to a party. This allows you to tactically place your clerics where they need to be, and generally makes your heroes almost invulnerable.

Enemy spawn rates increased: If you do not plan accordingly, you can have your low level heroes die to hordes of rats and skeletons while your better heroes are off doing the objective. Guard towers fix this problem easily, but I like to keep them to a minimum so that my heroes can level up and acquire gold for upgrades.

More upgrades: Your casters now gain magic attack when they upgrade their weapons, and every class has a plethora of upgrades to purchase.

I've read many reviews saying this game is too difficult. Without spoiling too much, learn the strengths and weaknesses of the heroes and learn how to set up and properly defend your economy, if your tax collectors die, you get no gold. Do not overlook palace upgrades. Remember your build orders so you can try something different if you fail.

reviewText:
Seeing so many negative reviews its a shame I can't add my review to Majesty 2 since I own the Collection edition. So here will suffice. I rate this game 8.5/10 and I played the original Majesty too (rate:9/10). M2 is a sim  RTS+RPG game, Like RTS games you have create an economy, research, create armies and destroy the opponents. The sim part is because you don't control the units (caled heroes). You assign rewards to kill a monster or destroy a building and depending on the reward 0 or more of your heroes will go achieve your task (more money = more heroes). There are soe 5 different kinds of tasks you can assign to heroes. The heroes will buy themselves upgrades provided that you created the necessary buildings and invested  on the research (which cost gold). Placing the buildings is your task and its important. There are defense towers and many other kinds of buildings (15+). Heroes level as they gain more experience (RPG component). I love this whole concept of the Majesty series.

Plus points:

- Unique take on RTS
- A variety of heroes: gnomes, archers, paladins, monks, necromancers (some 15+ types)
- Rock-paper-scissors system. .
- Varied gameplay in the campaign.
- RPG element s great. You can check each of your heroes and see what spells/powers they have learned.
- Game is well polished.

Minus points:

- Some of the latter missions are way too difficult. Basically, large number of monsters are thrown on your base before you even got the chance to set your economy. This frustrates the last 1/3 of the campaign. The first 2/3 are great. Its a shame. Maybe they should have add difficulty levels.
- So there are cheats and the player is forced to either spend hours figuring out how to beat each of these later missions or use the cheats, which is a shame either way.
- The concept is so amazing, one can't help feel that they could have designed a better campaign. One of the (hard) missions is to defeat two opposing kingdoms. It is incredibly cool as each of the opponents is using different armies. They could have thought other missions like that.

reviewText:
I'm writing this review because It bothers me how little notoriety majesty gets

Majesty 1 and Majesty 2 are both incredibly entertaining games that have value that long outlives their price point. Don't let my hours played fool you. I owned these games before steam was so common place and have likely sunk over 100 hours into Majesty 1 and at least 70 or so into Majesty 2.

But what is the game like? Well, Majesty is an RTS game yes, but it is best described as being god of your own little fantasy MMORPG. Your units in the game act on their own free will, and you must tempt them to do deeds for the kingdom by setting up quests for them to accomplish in the game by way of bounties. It's an unusual system, that can occassionally be difficult to get the hang of, but once you do it feels natural.

Like players in an MMO your units will level up, learn skills, & go to the shops and buy potions, weapons, armor, and whatever magic trinkets your market might have for sale. One of them might even get lucky and come across an extremely powerful weapon early in the game and go on to become a powerful lord of your land, valliantly defending against hordes of creatures that instantly wipe out your younger units, giving them breathing room to grow in power.

I could ramble on for much longer about why I love this game, but I'll try to throw together a good old fashion pro's and cons list

Pro's:
-Beautiful fantasy art style and graphics. Every unit in the game looks great right from the start, but as they level up and purchase new weapons and armor their appearance changes in a satisfying and meaningful way. A level 1 warrior looks like nothing compared to a level 15 warrior.

-Combat, while not being super involved on the part of the player, is always satsifying and fun to watch. As your units learn new skills either from training at a guild, or from leveling up, the way they fight changes. It's always neat to see the heroes fighting in new ways as the game goes on.

-Intimidating monsters and quests that will challenge you. Because of the unusual method for defending your kingdom, it's not nearly so easy to defend in this game. Bunkering up with thousands of troops is not something you can do, so proper management is something you'll have to learn

-Great silly voice acting from the royal advisor, and many good lines from your units. The dialog is just fun, that's all there really is to say about that.

-Economics are easy to grasp, not spreadsheet material, but not ♥♥♥♥ easy either. You will run out of money, and you will suffer for it, but you wont need a college degree to figure out how to maintain your kingdom.

Con's:

-The game is hard, and if you've never played a majesty game before, then you're going to have a bit of a rough time starting out (Though for some this can easily be a pro)

-It's frontloaded. Many missions are only hard at the start. By the time you establish your kingdom and have several powerful heroes wandering around, you'll easily take the rest of the mission by storm. (This is more of a problem with the vanilla campaign, and not so much with the DLC's)

-Takes forever to unlock everything. You will have to complete over 70% of the in game missions to have every building and unit unlocked. This can be frustrating if your favorite unit or building is one of the very last to be unlocked.

-AI is sometimes very stupid. Generally your units will do fine without your guidance and only need you to give them a quest for something majorly out of the way, like to raid an enemy keep, or defend a trading post. But sometimes a unit will choose to go to the store when a lich is about to blow their house to smithereens, and....well that is annoying.

reviewText:
This was the game I was looking for.  I discovered Majesty as a mobile app, and when I read that it was a port from PC (a well-done port, in my opinion), I decided to get it here on Steam.  I also got Majesty and Majesty HD, and while fundamentally similar in gameplay, they don't have the polished graphics that Majesty 2 has, and have that feel of a game a bit too old to get into in 2014.  If only I had played it a decade ago and had nostalgia driving me to return.

So in short, if you're looking for something different in RTS, namely a game where you don't directly control the heroes you've created, this is well worth some play time.  You build buildings and train adventurers of various classes.  You choose upgrades to stock the stores you've erected.  The adventurers you train will go out and explore and kill stuff, then buy items from the stores, provided you've researched the items they can afford.  When you want something killed or an area explored, you set a bounty and the adventurers decide who goes to collect.  The graphics aren't going to blow you away, but they're well-drawn and the game mechanics are a lot of fun.

One thing I've struggled with a bit: I haven't found any selectable difficulty options, and the levels are all laid out linearly despite being displayed on a map as though you could just select what challenge you're ready for.  When you progress to a difficult level, it is difficult and there isn't a lot you can do about it but retry until you figure out what you need to upgrade in what order.  This makes for a bit of tedium as you play for ten minutes and figure out that you lost in the first minute.  The only thing you can take with you between levels are heroes you've promoted to 'Lord' status, and if you've got some lords who are of a decent level but not too good you might be able to get a jump on a tough level, assuming you have enough starting gold to pay for the Hall of Lords and also to hire the lords, (the better they are, the more they cost, which limits the number of times you can do this as they will inevitably level up and cost more the next time you need them).  Outside of that, most levels require you to figure out the exact order to upgrade the exact right type of troops for each map, which removes any illusion of free will in how you approach each level, and a bit of the fun.

Bottom line: very challenging, bit more linear than I was hoping for, but a solid RTS-with-a-twist.

reviewText:
This game....this game.

It is not a Majesty 2 as it is significantly different from Majesty and for this alone the game recieved a lot of negative feedback.
This game is more strategic and difficult, compared to the prequel. Majesty one really was about a Kingdom simulation, Majesty 2 is a RTS with heavy RPG elements.

But if you just let Majesty be itself and not compare it to 1, it has very good gameplay.
There are enough scenarios and campaigns for everyone, the maps are all very different and varied, the game is challenging, but not unfair. And with the bundled DLC, there are a lot of different types of units to try out that all come with around 8 special abilities unlocked by levels.

The RPG mechanics can create funny situations. One of my favourite was when my heroes battled a huge dragon and everything was well, then suddenly, just in in an MMO raid, my eldest wizard casts his best nuke and gets the dragons attention, making the dragon turn towards him and breath fire. Of course, all healers and casters were at that spot....
It also feels very rewarding to groom your little heroes from wielding the stereotypiccal wooden sword to dueling dragons in their runic armor.
Or babysitting the wizard that died to a rat 7 times until he can level whole armies with one spell...while making sure the rest of the kingdom doesnt crumble underneath you.

However, there are two issues.
The first one is that the middle missions in the first campaign can fail at the very start, which is a source for a lot of anger directed at this game. What happens is that those missions throw monsters at the player very early and its pure luck if they attack something useless and thus let the player get out his first heroes to defend himself, or of they attack something important like a builder and thus significantly cripple the player in the first minutes, making him fight an impossible fight.
This issue was however fixed in all other campaigns, its unfortunate that the first few missions expose the new players to this.

The other issue is that the last campaign simply crashes and is not finishable for the majority. This is a serious nagetive point.



All in all, i can recommend this game to people who like a challenge and want to try something new. The RPG mechanics are fun!

reviewText:
This is a great game that takes a departure from stnadard RTS games in that you don't have direct control over your units. You start each level with a castle and you have to build various guilds and economic structures in order to grow your kingdom. You decide which buildings to build, which things to upgrade, and how many units to train. The only resource is money, and it is handled either throw your own economy of units buying things at the marketplace to improve their stats, or by building trading posts. Units will interact with buildings by buying better armor, potions, etc. and begin to level up as they face off against creatures that attack you kindgdom. You can manipulate your heroes by assigning reward flags to targets, setting explore flags, or setting defend flags. Each level is designed with a particular objective (kill a target, gather enough gold, defend for x number of days, etc)

There is lots of unit variety, from rogues, to archers, mages, warriors, and then high level units which have powerful abilities later on in the game. There are also lots of things to upgrade, and many unit combination to explore once you can build inns and form parties. Leveling your units is also satisfying as they learn powerful skills and maul their enemies in the most impressive and satisfying ways. This game is incredibly addicting once you get the hang of it, and missions easily span hours at a time. Graphically the game holds up great and things animate and look reasonably well. There is some nice humour thrown in for good measure with your advisor having a rather amusing sean-connory-like voice. Also your units say random things as they go about their business in your kingdom, so this game has quite a bit of charm. However, I will say that there isn't much of a story, but the mission scenarios feel varied enough with you having to fight all sorts of mystical creatures in intereting ways.

As far as difficulty, about half way through the game it skyrockets. The premise of the game is to manage to build a starting kingdom with limited resources that can fend off attackers. Once you get comfortable and money starts rolling in you, you can amass a grand army and plow pretty much anything. The issue is that you have to become very clever with where you put guard towers, and were you position your marketplace/guilds. Especially in the later missions, older strategies won't work and you'll have to do a lot of trial and error to figure things out, ie. it almost becomes a puzzle game. This game is definitely not for the faint of heart and it gets really HARD. Reading guides online is sometimes the only way to progress (it's totally frustrating, but also totally worth it once you figure things out). In my case, I couldn't get passed only 2 missions, so I used a hack to get extra money at the start, which is another option to make certain missions more enjoyable.

This collection comes with 4 games. The original majesty 2, 2 expansions which just add extra missions, and then the Monster Kingdom. The first 2 expansions ramp up the difficulty even more and I recommend staying away from them unless you really like this game. The last expansion swaps your human-like kingdom for a monster-kingom. The difficulty is much better balanced and makes for a better expeience.

In sum, I have put in 25 hours over the course of 3 days into this game (it is hellishly addicting once you get going). In total there is probably 50+ hours packed into this package. I can heartily recommend giving this game a go, because it's an experience unlike any you've ever had. Just be prepared for the difficulty spike (so use those internets to your advantage).

reviewText:
This is of course a sequel to Majesty: The Fantasy Kingdom Sim, just a collection with all the DLC (think expansion packs, not just small additions though there are a few). I recommend picking the original up if you can handle dated graphics, the gold edition is available on Steam as well but that's not what this review is for.

Like the original game you play as the King of Ardania, who with your trusty comedic aide/advisor you build a fairly simplistic kingdom of a market, blacksmith, guardhouses and various guilds to train Heroes. Heroes are the key to this game as they are the characters that will fight your battles and you have the most influence over. Influence is the best word because you cannot directly command them to do anything, just merely suggest they do some tasks by setting bounties (attack, explore, defend) as well as a fear flag which while it isn't a bountie in the true sense, they work on the same mechanics.

The campaign chronicles the journey to become the undisputed King of Ardania, as time progressed from the first king (from the first game) each king has tried to secure their place in history with grander feats of bravery. Lets just say the last king didn't do so well and you should watch the opening cinematic to see the bravery your forebearers had. The campaign is missioned based and you generally need to complete each mission to progress to the next ones, they generally unlock one or two missions at the same time and for replay value the tutorial is completely optional. Be warned, it does start simple but you do get a large difficulty spike later.

I recommend a Majesty game to anyone who is remotely interested in the premise of the game, this is a worthy sequel but the changes made sort of balance out the improvements made to make it equivalent to the original. The biggest difference from the original (for me) is most heroes will not respond to your bounties quickly unless you put some real money on them, not necessarily a bad thing because it does seem you get more gold income but it can be slightly annoying if you're used to the original. If you want this as an updated version of Majesty you won't be dissapointed, though you may find yourself wanting a bit more.

While this game definitely has enough thought and love put into it to appeal to some players, I found my expierence ultimately frustrating right up to 'Quit To Desktop.'

Majesty 2 is a fantasy RTS. You have a base, you have enemies, you have units and production buildings. A lot of the makings of this game are familiar to anyone who has played any sort of PC RTS game.

It contrasts harshly, though, with its RTS kin by taking a simulator-approach to control, much more in the camps of Sim City and Tropico than the combat RTSes that you're probably familiar with. This is the primary problem with the game, though. A central, defining mechanic, is that you cannot command units. You can't really command anyone to do anything. Much more like commanding humans in the real world, you can more or less dump breadcrumbs an incentives at objectives, and hope that units will wander along and do your bidding. This works very well in the mentioned simulator titles, because the game's goals are very loosely time-sensitive, and often the challenge you are attempting to defeat is an effeciency quota, or a highscore. It becomes problematic when your objectives are to not be slaughtered by the skeletons that are tearing your castle down.

Placing a reward miles away from your base at an enemy dungeon is the only way to get adventurers to meander over there and eliminate the threat. But, the amount of response time between placing a reward and your little lemming's arrival is so significant, huge events can occur before one adventurer sets eyes on the lair.

Like, say, an army of skeletons.
And, if this were to occur, I am sure in the real world, a lord would just recall his lair-bounty in favor of base defense. Well, no such luck. Even dumping a larger pot of gold at on your doorstep doesn't seem to help, so often you will encounter odd situations like the destruction of your base, as you watch your would-be defenders weakly beating goblins in the woods somewhere.

I am sure that these problems could be overcome with proper diligence, stragety, and patience, portioning miniscule rewards for objectives and just waiting their completion out. But, when exploring the game's mechanics and worlds, Majesty 2 tends to respond to any sort of failure with slow, plodding frustration, and the rewards for playing effectively feel so anticlimactic that after a very short period of time, I couldn't take anymore. I dumped all my gold in the woods; The skeletons can have my castle.
